turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: --Generally, Your Honor, they're required to at least dream it up before they finish the case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Uh-huh.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: As opposed to relying on this Court to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah, but nevertheless--

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: --dream up a justification for them.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, I know, but judges might think that... that they... even if one isn't suggested, the judges might think there is one.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, unless they articulate what that might be, it's very difficult for this Court to hypothesize what reasoning may have gone into a decision which does not support that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what if we thought... what if we thought there was a perfectly good reason for that?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: Your Honor--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are we forbidden to affirm?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: --If you believed that was consistent with constitutional... equal protection analysis--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, how about... how about... is it consistent with our cases?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: --I believe it is not in... it is not consistent with your cases to make such a conclusion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, there certainly are cases from this Court that say that we may speculate as to what a rational basis would have been.
Williams v. Lee Optical Company,--

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm not going to confess... I'm not going to assert that I'm familiar with that particular decision.
In general, I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --In any event, we do speculate--

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --And, in any event, we do speculate.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: Well, certainly, in this case you wouldn't speculate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Believe it, Mr. O'Keefe.
No.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: After all, it's just a wasted word.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_okeefe
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, that... it is the state's contention that it's a wasted word.
But, of course, there... every use of the words in the Constitution are presumed intentional and meaningful and not surplusage.

I'd also like to just point out that the state has conceded that it believes that this Board of Freeholders... first of all, it abandoned the reasoning of the Missouri Supreme Court to justify the relief they seek now, but also that they have contended that the Board of Freeholders process is equivalent to the state legislature and the right of initiative, and have even suggested to this Court that it would be an appropriate application of a rational standard to limit... in response to the question asked previously... to limit the opportunity to introduce bills in the Missouri legislature to only property owners.
Presumably they also suggest it would be rational to limit the right of initiative to property owners.
Essentially what they are suggesting is that Missouri is to be a two-tiered class... a two-class society.

One class, the landed gentry allowed to participate at the front and back end of the governmental process, while those who do not enjoy the privilege, are allowed to participate only at the back end of the process.
A hundred and forty-seven years ago this month, the citizens of the State of Rhode Island went into rebellion.
Armed rebellion in the streets for the purpose of protecting the right of the participation in government, free of a property ownership qualification.
The doors rebellion was a sad chapter in that state's history and in this country's history.
But the appellants in this case seek no more greater right than that.
Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. O'Keefe.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at ten o'clock.
